ElasticSearch h2. A Distributed RESTful Search Engine h3. "http://www.elasticsearch.org":http://www.elasticsearch.org ElasticSearch is a distributed RESTful search engine built for the cloud. Features include: * Distributed and Highly Available Search Engine. ** Each index is fully sharded with a configurable number of shards. ** Each shard can have one or more replicas. ** Read / Search operations performed on either one of the replica shard. * Multi Tenant with Multi Types. ** Support for more than one index. ** Support for more than one type per index. ** Index level configuration (number of shards, index storage, ...). * Various set of APIs ** HTTP RESTful API ** Native Java API. ** All APIs perform automatic node operation rerouting. * Document oriented ** No need for upfront schema definition. ** Schema can be defined per type for customization of the indexing process. * Reliable, Asynchronous Write Behind for long term persistency. * (Near) Real Time Search. * Built on top of Lucene ** Each shard is a fully functional Lucene index ** All the power of Lucene easily exposed through simple configuration / plugins. * Per operation consistency ** Single document level operations are atomic, consistent, isolated and durable. * Open Source under Apache 2 License. h2. Getting Started First of all, DON'T PANIC. It will take 5 minutes to get the gist of what ElasticSearch is all about. h3. Installation * "Download":http://www.elasticsearch.org/download and unzip the ElasticSearch official distribution. * Run @bin/elasticsearch -f@ on unix, or @bin/elasticsearch.bat@ on windows. * Run @curl -X GET http://localhost:9200/@. * Start more servers ... h3. Indexing Lets try and index some twitter like information. First, lets create a twitter user, and add some tweets (the @twitter@ index will be created automatically): 
curl -XPUT 'http://localhost:9200/twitter/user/kimchy' -d '{ "name" : "Shay Banon" }'

curl -XPUT 'http://localhost:9200/twitter/tweet/1' -d '
{ 
    "user": "kimchy", 
    "postDate": "2009-11-15T13:12:00", 
    "message": "Trying out Elastic Search, so far so good?" 
}'

curl -XPUT 'http://localhost:9200/twitter/tweet/2' -d '
{ 
    "user": "kimchy", 
    "postDate": "2009-11-15T14:12:12", 
    "message": "Another tweet, will it be indexed?" 
}'
Now, lets see if the information was added by GETting it: 
curl -XGET 'http://localhost:9200/twitter/user/kimchy?pretty=true'
curl -XGET 'http://localhost:9200/twitter/tweet/1?pretty=true'
curl -XGET 'http://localhost:9200/twitter/tweet/2?pretty=true'
h3. Searching Mmm search..., shouldn't it be elastic? Lets find all the tweets that @kimchy@ posted: 
curl -XGET 'http://localhost:9200/twitter/tweet/_search?q=user:kimchy&pretty=true'
We can also use the JSON query language ElasticSearch provides instead of a query string: 
curl -XGET 'http://localhost:9200/twitter/tweet/_search?pretty=true' -d '
{ 
    "query" : { 
        "text" : { "user": "kimchy" }
    } 
}'
Just for kicks, lets get all the documents stored (we should see the user as well): 
curl -XGET 'http://localhost:9200/twitter/_search?pretty=true' -d '
{ 
    "query" : { 
        "matchAll" : {} 
    } 
}'
We can also do range search (the @postDate@ was automatically identified as date) 
curl -XGET 'http://localhost:9200/twitter/_search?pretty=true' -d '
{ 
    "query" : { 
        "range" : { 
            "postDate" : { "from" : "2009-11-15T13:00:00", "to" : "2009-11-15T14:00:00" } 
        } 
    } 
}'
There are many more options to perform search, after all, its a search product no? All the familiar Lucene queries are available through the JSON query language, or through the query parser. h3. Multi Tenant - Indices and Types Maan, that twitter index might get big (in this case, index size == valuation). Lets see if we can structure our twitter system a bit differently in order to support such large amount of data. ElasticSearch support multiple indices, as well as multiple types per index. In the previous example we used an index called @twitter@, with two types, @user@ and @tweet@. Another way to define our simple twitter system is to have a different index per user (though note that an index has an overhead). Here is the indexing curl's in this case: 
curl -XPUT 'http://localhost:9200/kimchy/info/1' -d '{ "name" : "Shay Banon" }'

curl -XPUT 'http://localhost:9200/kimchy/tweet/1' -d '
{ 
    "user": "kimchy", 
    "postDate": "2009-11-15T13:12:00", 
    "message": "Trying out Elastic Search, so far so good?" 
}'

curl -XPUT 'http://localhost:9200/kimchy/tweet/2' -d '
{ 
    "user": "kimchy", 
    "postDate": "2009-11-15T14:12:12", 
    "message": "Another tweet, will it be indexed?" 
}'
The above index information into the @kimchy@ index, with two types, @info@ and @tweet@. Each user will get his own special index. Complete control on the index level is allowed. As an example, in the above case, we would want to change from the default 5 shards with 1 replica per index, to only 1 shard with 1 replica per index (== per twitter user). Here is how this can be done (the configuration can be in yaml as well): 
curl -XPUT http://localhost:9200/another_user/ -d '
{ 
    "index" : { 
        "numberOfShards" : 1, 
        "numberOfReplicas" : 1 
    } 
}'
Search (and similar operations) are multi index aware. This means that we can easily search on more than one index (twitter user), for example: 
curl -XGET 'http://localhost:9200/kimchy,another_user/_search?pretty=true' -d '
{ 
    "query" : { 
        "matchAll" : {} 
    } 
}'
Or on all the indices: 
curl -XGET 'http://localhost:9200/_search?pretty=true' -d '
{ 
    "query" : { 
        "matchAll" : {} 
    } 
}'
{One liner teaser}: And the cool part about that? You can easily search on multiple twitter users (indices), with different boost levels per user (index), making social search so much simpler (results from my friends rank higher than results from my friends friends). h3. Distributed, Highly Available Lets face it, things will fail.... ElasticSearch is a highly available and distributed search engine. Each index is broken down into shards, and each shard can have one or more replica. By default, an index is created with 5 shards and 1 replica per shard (5/1). There are many topologies that can be used, including 1/10 (improve search performance), or 20/1 (improve indexing performance, with search executed in a map reduce fashion across shards). In order to play with Elastic Search distributed nature, simply bring more nodes up and shut down nodes. The system will continue to serve requests (make sure you use the correct http port) with the latest data indexed. h3. Where to go from here? We have just covered a very small portion of what ElasticSearch is all about. For more information, please refer to the "elasticsearch.org":http://www.elasticsearch.org website. h3. Building from Source ElasticSearch uses "Maven":http://maven.apache.org for its build system. In order to create a distribution, simply run the @mvn clean package -DskipTests@ command in the cloned directory. The distribution will be created under @target/releases@. See the "TESTING":TESTING.asciidoc file for more information about running the Elasticsearch test suite. h1. License

It includes: - `ElasticsearchTestCase` - Base test case with common utilities - `AbstractIntegrationTest` - Integration test support with cluster management - `TestCluster` - Managed test cluster for integration tests - Additional testing utilities in sub-packages ## Maven Dependency To use the Elasticsearch test framework in your project, add the following dependency to your `pom.xml`: ```xml org.elasticsearch elasticsearch 1.0.0.Beta2-SNAPSHOT test-jar test org.apache.lucene lucene-test-framework 4.5.1 test org.hamcrest hamcrest-all 1.3 test ``` ## Basic Usage ### Using ElasticsearchTestCase ```java import org.elasticsearch.test.ElasticsearchTestCase; import org.junit.Test; public class MyTestCase extends ElasticsearchTestCase { @Test public void testSomething() { // Use the provided utilities String numericType = randomNumericType(random()); logger.info("Testing with numeric type: {}", numericType); // Your test code here } } ``` ### Using AbstractIntegrationTest ```java import org.elasticsearch.test.AbstractIntegrationTest; import org.junit.Test; import static org.elasticsearch.test.hamcrest.ElasticsearchAssertions.assertAcked; public class MyIntegrationTest extends AbstractIntegrationTest { @Test public void testIndexCreation() { // Create an index assertAcked(client().admin().indices().prepareCreate("test-index") .setSettings(numberOfShards(1)) .get()); // Your integration test code here } } ``` ## Available Test Utilities ### Core Classes - `ElasticsearchTestCase` - Base class with common test utilities - `AbstractIntegrationTest` - Base for integration tests with cluster - `TestCluster` - Manages test cluster lifecycle - `ElasticsearchLuceneTestCase` - Lucene-specific test utilities ### Asserts and Matchers - `ElasticsearchAssertions` - Custom assertions for Elasticsearch - Located in `org.elasticsearch.test.hamcrest` package ### Testing Support - Mock engines and stores in `org.elasticsearch.test.engine` and `org.elasticsearch.test.store` - Transport testing utilities in `org.elasticsearch.test.transport` ## Building the Test Framework The test framework is automatically built when you run: ``` mvn clean package ``` This will create: - `target/elasticsearch-1.0.0.Beta2-SNAPSHOT-tests.jar` - The test framework classes - `target/elasticsearch-1.0.0.Beta2-SNAPSHOT-test-sources.jar` - Test framework source code - `target/elasticsearch-1.0.0.Beta2-SNAPSHOT-test-javadoc.jar` - Test framework javadoc ## Notes 1. The test framework classes have a `provided` scope for their dependencies to avoid conflicts when used as a test dependency 2. Test classes are excluded from the test jar - only the framework classes are included 3. The framework includes both Elasticsearch-specific test utilities and Lucene test framework integration"},"timestamp":1763784207580,"session_id":"0df3102c-a733-41b5-841b-938492134742"} {"type":"tool_result","id":"call_nk0EWjNbi0MkMzOPMXF5cBKa","messageId":"f7e3cce3-d84d-4ab9-959b-fdd884785d75","toolId":"","isError":false,"value":"TODO List Updated","timestamp":1763784210079,"session_id":"0df3102c-a733-41b5-841b-938492134742"} {"type":"message","role":"assistant","id":"9ed46739-c005-4cab-8f91-d79d0f6061d4","text":"Now let me test the build to verify that the test jar is correctly created:","timestamp":1763784210076,"session_id":"0df3102c-a733-41b5-841b-938492134742"} {"type":"tool_call","id":"call_nk0EWjNbi0MkMzOPMXF5cBKa","messageId":"9ed46739-c005-4cab-8f91-d79d0f6061d4","toolId":"TodoWrite","toolName":"TodoWrite","parameters":{"todos":[{"content":"Explore project structure to understand current test framework setup","id":"explore_project","priority":"high","status":"completed"},{"content":"Identify test framework classes that need to be packaged","id":"identify_test_classes","priority":"high","status":"completed"},{"content":"Check current build configuration (pom.xml) for packaging setup","id":"check_build_config","priority":"high","status":"completed"},{"content":"Configure Maven to package test framework as separate jar","id":"configure_packaging","priority":"high","status":"completed"},{"content":"Verify the packaged test framework can be used as dependency","id":"verify_packaging","priority":"medium","status":"in_progress"}]},"timestamp":1763784210076,"session_id":"0df3102c-a733-41b5-841b-938492134742"} {"type":"tool_result","id":"call_UOFbmLlLqjz4Vym23F6W5zFm","messageId":"c6f1dd4e-d572-4af8-b301-9c12a41036e7","toolId":"","isError":false,"value":"Error: Command not found. Test Framework =========================== This package contains the test framework classes from Elasticsearch that can be used as a test dependency in external projects. Included Framework Classes: -------------------------- Core Test Classes: - org.elasticsearch.test.ElasticsearchTestCase - org.elasticsearch.test.AbstractIntegrationTest - org.elasticsearch.test.TestCluster - org.elasticsearch.test.ElasticsearchLuceneTestCase - org.elasticsearch.test.ElasticsearchTokenStreamTestCase - org.elasticsearch.test.ElasticsearchThreadFilter Test Utilities: - org.elasticsearch.test.engine.* (Engine testing support) - org.elasticsearch.test.store.* (Store testing support) - org.elasticsearch.test.transport.* (Transport testing support) - org.elasticsearch.test.junit.* (JUnit testing support) - org.elasticsearch.test.hamcrest.* (Custom Hamcrest matchers) Lucene Integration: - org.apache.lucene.util.AbstractRandomizedTest - org.apache.lucene.util.LuceneTestCase - Related Lucene testing utilities Usage: ----- To use this test framework in your project, add the following dependencies to your pom.xml: ```xml org.elasticsearch elasticsearch 1.0.0.Beta2-SNAPSHOT test-jar test org.apache.lucene lucene-test-framework 4.5.1 test org.hamcrest hamcrest-all 1.3 test ``` Example Usage: ------------- ```java import org.elasticsearch.test.ElasticsearchTestCase; import org.junit.Test; public class MyTestCase extends ElasticsearchTestCase { @Test public void testSomething() { // Use the provided utilities String numericType = randomNumericType(random()); logger.info("Testing with numeric type: {}", numericType); // Your test code here } } ``` For integration tests: ```java import org.elasticsearch.test.AbstractIntegrationTest; import org.junit.Test; import static org.elasticsearch.test.hamcrest.ElasticsearchAssertions.assertAcked; public class MyIntegrationTest extends AbstractIntegrationTest { @Test public void testIndexCreation() { // Create an index using the test cluster assertAcked(client().admin().indices().prepareCreate("test-index") .setSettings(numberOfShards(1)) .get()); } } ``` Maven Configuration: ------------------- The test framework is packaged as a test-jar using the maven-jar-plugin configuration: ```xml org.apache.maven.plugins maven-jar-plugin 2.4 create-test-jar package test-jar org/elasticsearch/test/** org/elasticsearch/test/engine/** org/elasticsearch/test/store/** org/elasticsearch/test/transport/** org/elasticsearch/test/junit/** org/elasticsearch/test/hamcrest/** org/apache/lucene/util/AbstractRandomizedTest.class org/apache/lucene/util/LuceneTestCase.class org/elasticsearch/**/*Tests.class org/elasticsearch/**/*Test.class org/apache/lucene/**/*Tests.class org/apache/lucene/**/*Test.class ``` Dependencies: ------------ The test framework dependencies are configured with 'provided' scope to avoid conflicts when used as a test dependency: ```xml org.hamcrest hamcrest-all 1.3 provided org.apache.lucene lucene-test-framework ${lucene.version} provided ``` Notes: ----- - Test classes are excluded from the test jar - only the framework classes are included - Framework includes both Elasticsearch-specific test utilities and Lucene test framework integration - When built with `mvn clean package`, it will generate: - `elasticsearch-1.0.0.Beta2-SNAPSHOT-tests.jar` - The test framework classes - `elasticsearch-1.0.0.Beta2-SNAPSHOT-test-sources.jar` - Test framework source code - `elasticsearch-1.0.0.Beta2-SNAPSHOT-test-javadoc.jar` - Test framework
